clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Visual Training in Beach Tennis
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Visual Training in Beach Tennis - a Pilot Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Wrocław University of Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Wrocław University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: The proposed protocol is going to study the importance of wide spread of visual functions defined by but not limited to visual perception, visual function, visual exploration, involved in the performance of beach tennis. The investigators intend to examine the basic and important visual function that are required for the better performance in the field. The aim is to assess the efficacy of general training that uses the visual channel as the main one. The investigators suspects the improvement in the visual and motor skills after a predefined 8 weeks of visual training.

primary_outcome.description: The reaction time between the visual stimulus and the motor reaction

secondary_outcome.description: Best-corrected visual acuity in static conditions expressed in logMAR
Best-corrected visual acuity in dynamic conditions expressed in logMAR
Overall performance of the player during the supervised match [percentage of properly conducted series of moves specific to rocket sports]

other_outcome.description: Checking the pace of macular fixation in the predefined text of equal lenght of words.

other_outcome.measure: Reading rate during the optokinetic task
other_outcome.description: Checking the reading rate during the optokinetic task.

arm_group.description: Pre-specidied visual training methods that use: the Marsden ball, tables that uses green-red visual stimuli, physical reation in response to the visual stimuli that uses the flippers or the preselected distances. One set of exercises per week was prepared. Each visual training will last for 15 minutes and should be performed by the participant in their home (using the telemedicine devices to control the conduction of each exercise) 3 times a week.

intervention.description: Pre-defined visual training protocol including the optometrical unit exercises

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- experienced beach tennis player
- participants able and willing to participate in the study (including telemedicine supervision during the training phase)
- known and using full spectacles correction or its equivalent in contact lens correction
Exclusion Criteria:
- inability to give an informed consent
- any disease that causes visual opacity that unable to perform visual training
- participant unable to conduct full visual training course of the study
